;;2023 年 10 月 20 日，交易员在美国纽约市纽约证券交易所 (NYSE) 的交易大厅工作。 REUTERS/ Brendan McDermid;
;

;周二，华尔街主要股指苦苦寻找方向，因为投资者在评估最新一批收益报告的同时，等待美联储货币政策会议的结果。

;

;大型成长型股票周一在华尔街上涨了 1% 以上，但在周二却拖累了股市。

;

;元平台 ;(META.O);，微软 ;(MSFT.O); 和 Alphabet ;(GOOGL.O);下跌 0.4% 到 1% 之间。

;

;Nvidia ;(NVDA.O) ; 下跌 2.6%，;报告;称，美国最新的限制措施可能会迫使这家芯片设计商取消对中国数十亿美元的订单。

;

;标准普尔 500 指数 11 个主要板块中有 7 个板块是绿色，房地产 ;(.SPLRCR); 上涨 1.2%，领涨，而通信服务;(.SPLRCL);则下降了0.4%

;

;美联储周二开始为期两天的货币政策会议。根据芝商所的 FedWatch 工具，人们普遍预计会议结束时美联储将维持利率稳定。

;

;美联储对周三和周五月度非农就业报告的评论对于评估利率会持续多久至关重要货币政策可能会保持限制性。

;

;“今天的市场相当没有趋势，也没有友好的环境。每个人都在等待美联储的决定和周五的就业报告，”休·约翰逊董事长兼首席经济学家休·约翰逊表示经济。

;

;“自7月下旬以来，投资者开始变得担忧，因为硬着陆的可能性增加。这就是为什么今天对（美联储）如此关注。”

;

;数据显示第三季度美国劳动力成本;大幅增长;担心美联储可能会在更长时间内维持较高的利率。

;

;在盈利方面，重型机械制造商卡特彼勒;(CAT.N); 下跌 5.8%，原因是机械需求放缓的迹象掩盖了季度盈利的表现。

;

;制药商 ;安进;;(AMGN.O); 下跌 3.7%，原因是一些知名药品第三季度的销量低于预期。

;

; 根据 LSEG 的数据，迄今为止，标准普尔 500 指数中有 279 家公司公布了盈利情况，其中超过 78% 的公司超出了分析师的预期。分析师预计标普 500 指数成分股公司第三季度盈利将增长 4.9%。

;

;美国股市连续第三个月下跌，其中标普 500 指数成分股;(.SPX); 和纳斯达克 ;(.IXIC); 有望迎来自 2018 年以来最大的 10 月份百分比跌幅。

;

;美国东部时间上午 11:47，道琼斯工业平均指数 ;(.DJI); 下跌 33.53 点，跌幅 0.10%，至 32,895.43 点;(.SPX); 上涨 0.09 点，即 0.00%，至 4,166.91 点，纳斯达克综合指数下跌 37.01 点，跌幅 0.29%，至 12,752.48 点。

;

;;Pinterest; ;(PINS.N); 上涨 18.6%，图片共享平台第三季度收入和利润均超过预期估计。

;

;;Sarepta 疗法; ;(SRPT.O); 由于其失败而暴跌 41.7%后期试验中的肌肉疾病基因治疗。 Sarepta 的客户 Catalent ;(CTLT.N); 的股价也下跌了 16.9%。

;美国财报疲软，全球股市周二震荡，而前一天美联储预计将再次表示利率将保持在高位日本央行结束多年的货币刺激措施让投资者感到冷淡，导致日元下跌。

;

;尽管欧洲股市因投资者从强劲的地区业绩中获得安慰而上涨，但亚洲股市早些时候下跌疲软的制造业数据再次引发对中国经济前景的担忧。

;

;在华尔街，重型机械制造商;卡特彼勒; ;(CAT.N); 下跌 6.1%，因经销商库存增加且大量积压订单减少，表明需求正在放缓。制药商辉瑞 (Pfizer) 股价 ;(PFE.N); 下跌 1.7% ;报告;自 2019 年以来首次出现季度亏损。

;

;“第四季度的盈利预测正在下降，”密歇根州特洛伊市 Ameriprise Financial 首席市场策略师 Anthony Saglimbene 表示。 “这在很大程度上与标准普尔 500 指数公司的指引有关，该指引较为保守。”

;

;截至周五，标准普尔 500 指数公司第四季度盈利增长率已降至 8.5%，根据 LSEG 数据，预计 10 月 1 日将上涨 11.0%。

;

;与此同时，投资者正在等待周三结束的为期两天的政策会议后美联储将发表什么言论，这不太可能对过去的情况产生重大影响声明。

;

;“对于市场继续苦苦挣扎的较长消息，市场将继续走高，”萨格林贝内说。

;

;MSCI 以美国为中心的全球股票指数;(.MIWD00000PUS); 下跌 0.07%，而泛欧 STOXX 600 指数;(.STOXX); 上涨 0.59%。

;

;道琼斯工业平均指数;(.DJI); 下跌 0.1%，标准普尔 500 指数 ;(.SPX); 上涨 0.04%，纳斯达克综合指数 ;(.IXIC); 下跌 0.2%。

;

;日元下跌约 1.5%，至一年新低 151.32。日本央行进一步;放松债券收益率控制政策; (YCC) 分析师认为这是一个小而不足的步骤。

;

;日元下跌，因为交易员关注日本央行“耐心”维持宽松政策的鸽派承诺，并预测 2019 年通胀率将放缓至 2% 以下。 2025年。

;

;日元兑欧元也进一步走弱，单一货币上涨1.5%，至15年高点160.64。

;

;由于投资者观望，较长期国债收益率下跌美联储声明和美联储主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔的评论。

;

;基准 10 年期国债上周触及 16 年高点，原因是投资者考虑更长时间提高收益率，以及对美国国债供应增加的担忧。

;

; >;

;10 年期国债收益率下跌 2.5 个基点，至 4.852%。

;

;欧元区收益率下跌，因个别国家通胀数据显示当天晚些时候欧元区整体表现较低。德国基准 10 年期国债收益率下跌 5.5 个基点，至 2.77%，测试前一日的两周低点。

;

;亚洲股市早些时候因中国制造业活动而下滑 ;恢复收缩;，再次引发人们对世界第二大经济体的担忧。最近的指标显示中国刚刚开始复苏。

;

;衡量美元兑六种货币的美元指数上涨了 0.48%。欧元有望扭转连续两个月的跌势，10 月份上涨 0.3%。

;

;欧元最后上涨 0.3%，至 1.0662 美元。

;

;周二油价保持稳定欧元区通胀下降被欧佩克产量增加所平衡。

;

;美国原油近期下跌 0.06%，至每桶 82.26 美元，布伦特原油价格为 87.65 美元，当日上涨 0.23%。

; Tue, 31 Oct 2023 23:55:03 +0800 US daylight saving time: When do clocks change and why was it created?https://reuters.com/article/usa-daylight/what-is-us-daylight-saving-time-and-why-was-it-created-idUSKBN31V0JF
;;2023-10-31T15:02:10Z;
;;
;;资料照片：中央车站时钟拍摄于纽约曼哈顿中央车站火车站的主大厅，美国，2021 年 5 月 27 日。路透社/Mike Segar/档案照片;
;

;美国、加拿大和古巴等国家准备在 11 月 5 日夏令时将时钟拨慢一小时结束后，美国;辩论再次出现;讨论是否以及如何;结束这种做法;。

;

;以下是您需要了解的有关夏令时以及结束夏令时的论据。

;

;夏令时是在夏季将时钟向前拨动一小时的做法，因此 ;日光持续时间更长;到晚上。北美和欧洲的大部分地区都遵循这一习俗，而其他地方的大多数国家，尤其是靠近赤道的国家则没有。

;

;这种做法从一开始就引起了争议，许多国家采用或拒绝多次。埃及于 3 月份宣布将;重新引入夏令时;经过七年的差距来合理化能源使用。日本曾考虑在 2020 年奥运会上采用这一做法，但由于缺乏民众支持和技术挑战而拒绝了该提议。

;

;美国和一些邻国的夏令时将于当地时间 11 月 5 日凌晨 2 点结束时间，将时钟拨慢一小时。

;

;在英国和其他欧洲国家，夏令时（也称为夏令时）于 10 月 29 日结束。

;

;夏令时始终对于美国，从 3 月的第二个星期日开始，到 11 月的第一个星期日结束。这与英国和欧盟形成鲜明对比，英国和欧盟的夏令时从三月的最后一个星期日开始，到十月的最后一个星期日结束。

;

;随着季节改变时钟的现代想法可以追溯到至少在 19 世纪末，新西兰;昆虫学家 George Hudson; 提出它是为了节省能源并延长夏季日照时间，这对他自己下班后收集昆虫的爱好有好处。

;

;这个想法一直很缓慢，直到第一次世界大战，当时欧洲国家寻求任何;节省燃料的策略;。德国于 1916 年成为第一个采用夏令时的国家，美国于 1918 年紧随其后。

;

;在美国于 1966 年通过《统一时间法案》将其标准化之前，这种做法经历了许多变化，该法案允许各州选择夏令时。一个常见的误解是，美国采用夏令时是为了让农民受益，但实际上许多;农民反对;这种扰乱他们日程安排的做法。

;

;原始;节省燃料的动机;是根据国会研究服务处的数据，研究发现这种转变几乎没有节省能源（如果有的话），这也引起了争论。

;

;反对者指出其他研究发现夏令时对健康产生不利影响，例如每年三月时钟提前一小时后的几天里，致命交通事故、心脏病、中风和睡眠不足的人数激增。

;

;不，夏威夷和亚利桑那州（纳瓦霍族除外）不会这样做不遵守夏令时。美属萨摩亚、关岛、北马里亚纳群岛、波多黎各和维尔京群岛也遵守永久标准时间。

;

;虽然美国各地普遍实行夏令时，但仍有 19 个州实行;通过立法;，如果国会允许，则永久使用夏令时

;

;美国不会很快结束夏令时，尽管联邦政府正在努力通过所谓的阳光保护法案，这将使夏令时永久化。< /p>;

;该法案由两党参议员组成，于 2022 年提出，内容为;以口头表决方式一致通过;，但在美国众议院陷入停滞，因为;众议员弗兰克·帕隆 (Frank Pallone) 在 3 月份表示，立法者无法就是否保留标准时间或永久夏令时达成一致;。

;

;该参议员小组今年再次重新提出该法案，并已提交商业、科学和运输委员会审查。该法案需要在参议院和众议院获得通过，然后总统乔·拜登才能签署成为法律。

;;这些被裹尸布包裹的尸体是以色列地面入侵该地带的受害者，正被送往飞地北部的印度尼西亚医院。周二（10 月 31 日）早上，当车抵达医疗机构外时，数十名加沙人在车旁奔跑，高喊“上帝伟大”。;
;

;以色列表示，其部队在武装分子的营地内与哈马斯枪手作战。加沙地下巨大的隧道网络，一名医院院长表示，以色列对被围困飞地的难民营进行空袭，造成 50 多名巴勒斯坦人死亡。

;

;随着哈马斯统治的巴勒斯坦领土内的战斗愈演愈烈，以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡驳回了国际社会要求停止战斗的呼吁。

;

;但联合国和其他援助官员警告说，一场公共卫生灾难正在席卷加沙平民，医院正在努力应对不断增加的伤亡和食物药品、饮用水和燃料短缺。

;

;加沙印度尼西亚医院院长告诉半岛电视台，以色列对贾巴利亚难民营人口稠密地区的空袭造成 50 多名巴勒斯坦人死亡，150 人受伤位于加沙北部。

;

;;FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried is questioned by prosecutor Danielle Sassoon (not seen) during his fraud trial over the collapse of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange at federal court in New York City, US, October 31, 2023 in this courtroom sketch. REUTERS/Jane Rosenberg;
;

;FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried was grilled on Tuesday about what a US prosecutor called his "cozy" relationship with officials in the Bahamas, where the cryptocurrency exchange was based before its November 2022 collapse.

;

;During Bankman-Fried's second day of cross-examination at his fraud trial, prosecutor Danielle Sassoon sought to link favors that he did for Bahamian officials with his decision to let FTX customers there withdraw their funds after withdrawals for others had been halted around Nov. 9, 2022.

;

;"I asked if that's what they had wanted me to do," Bankman-Fried said in Manhattan federal court, referring to the exemption for Bahamian users from the withdrawal ban.

;

;"And you did that, correct?" Sassoon asked.

;

;"Briefly," Bankman-Fried replied.

;

;The 31-year-old former billionaire has pleaded not guilty to two counts of fraud and five counts of conspiracy. Prosecutors have accused him of looting billions of dollars of customer funds to prop up his crypto-focused Alameda Research hedge fund, make speculative venture investments and donate upwards of $100 million to US political campaigns. If convicted, he could face decades in prison.

;

;Earlier in the trial, former FTX executive Gary Wang, who pleaded guilty to fraud and agreed to cooperate with prosecutors, testified that Bankman-Fried sought to transfer funds to the Bahamas after FTX's Nov. 11, 2022, US bankruptcy because he thought authorities might let him stay in charge.

;

;Bankman-Fried testified on Tuesday he could not remember whether he offered to pay off the Bahamas' national debt. Asked by Sassoon whether he offered the Bahamian prime minister's son a job, Bankman-Fried conceded that he had "offered to have a talk" with the son.

;

;The defendant also said he did not remember whether he gave the prime minister and his wife floorside seats at a Miami Heat National Basketball Association game. The arena had been named for FTX in a sponsorship deal.

;

;Sassoon then showed Bankman-Fried a text message in which he told co-workers the couple sat courtside at a game.

;

;Sassoon at one point asked Bankman-Fried whether he had "cultivated a cozy relationship" with the Bahamian government - a question to which the defense objected. Bankman-Fried testified that he had spent time with Bahamian officials and became close with "some of them."

;

;The embassy of the Bahamas in Washington did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

;

;Sassoon in her cross-examination often has asked Bankman-Fried about his public statements prior to FTX's collapse that keeping customer funds safe was a priority.

;

;Bankman-Fried has frequently said he did not recall making specific statements, and US District Judge Lewis Kaplan has often chided him for not answering Sassoon's questions directly.

;

;Under direct examination from his lawyers, Bankman-Fried had testified that he had made "mistakes" that hurt FTX customers and employees but denied defrauding anyone or stealing funds.

;President Joe Biden's support among Arab Americans, who are crucial voters in battleground election states, has plunged from a comfortable majority in 2020 to just 17%, a new poll shows, amid growing anger over the Democratic president's support for Israel's attacks on Gaza.

;

;Arab American support for Biden, at 59% in 2020, fell even before the outbreak of violence in the Middle East to 35%, the poll commissioned by the Arab American Institute showed, but has halved since.

;

;The poll, released Tuesday, marks the first time since its inception in 1997 that a majority of Arab Americans did not identify as Democrats - 32% now identify as Republicans and 31% as independents. Forty percent of those polled said they would vote for former President Donald Trump, the likely Republican candidate in 2024, up 5 percentage points from 2020.

;

;The poll is the latest evidence that Biden's campaign for a second term in office is rapidly losing ;Muslim and Arab Americans support; over his staunch support of Israel. ;

;A quarter of Arab Americans said they were unsure whom they would support in 2024; 13.7% said they would back Robert F. Kennedy Jr., and 3.8% are backing Cornel West.

;

;Only 20% of Arab Americans would rate Biden's job performance as "good," the poll showed, with 66% reporting a negative view of the president overall.

;

;Sixty-eight percent of Arab Americans believed the United States should not send weapons and military equipment to Israel and believed the US should use its influence with Israel to call for a ceasefire, it said.

;

;Majorities are concerned about rising antisemitism (67%) and anti-Arab bigotry (78%), and 59% report experiencing discrimination, a jump of 6% since the last poll in April.

;

;The poll showed that 45% of Arab Americans were concerned about their personal safety due to the recent violence in Israel and Palestine.

;

;CONTEXTMany ;Arab and Muslim Americans say they feel betrayed; by Biden's financial, political and military support for Israel's attacks on the Gaza Strip after an Oct. 7 attack by Hamas militants that Israeli officials say killed 1,400 people and took 239 hostages.

;

;Medical authorities in Gaza on Tuesday said ;8,525 people, including 3,542 children;, had been killed in Israel's three-week-old air and ground onslaught.

;

;The poll was conducted by John Zogby Strategies of 500 Arab Americans with some answering online only. The poll has a margin of error of 4.9 percentage points.

;;Members of the Palestine Red Crescent Society distribute aid to people in Deir al-Balah, in the central Gaza Strip, in this handout picture released on October 25, 2023. Palestine Red Crescent Society/Handout via REUTERS/File photo;
;

;Distribution of food and medical supplies is faltering in Gaza due to a chronic lack of fuel, looting of stores, the choking of streets with rubble from Israeli shelling and overcrowding caused by displacement of civilians.

;

;And despite an uptick in the trickle of supplies, the number of aid trucks entering Gaza -- currently averaging 14 daily -- remains tiny compared to the 400 trucks seen daily in normal times for a population of 2.3 million now desperate for essentials like bread, aid officials say.

;

;UN Palestinian refugee agency (UNRWA) said on Monday that over the past day it had delivered hundreds of tonnes of flour to 50 Gaza bakeries, helping to lower bread prices by half, and to shelters hosting hundreds of thousands of people.

;

;But the agency, which runs Gaza's largest aid operation, said a ;break-in; by hungry Gazans on Sunday at its second largest warehouse was likely to further complicate its work.

;

;A logistics base at the Rafah border crossing that is vital to aid distribution has become ;harder to operate; because 8,000 displaced people are sheltering at it.

;

;The agency has also seen 67 of its workers killed in Gaza since Oct. 7, the highest number of UN staff killed in any conflict in such a short span of time, it said.

;

;UNRWA spokesperson Juliette Touma said the agency's priority was providing aid to 150 shelters for at least 670,000 displaced people, while another priority was providing wheat flour to bakeries.

;

;"We're way beyond our capacity" to do anything more than that, she added.

;

;The number of displaced is four times more than UNRWA had planned for before the war as a worst case scenario, she said.

;

;The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies said their Gaza City warehouses had suffered "severe damage" on Monday and were out of service.

;

;Israel is blockading Gaza and refuses to allow in fuel, saying it could be used by the Hamas militant group for their military goals.

;

;"The constant threat of bombardment, debris, and lack of fuel makes roads extremely dangerous and inaccessible in many parts of the Gaza Strip," said Jonathan Crickx, communications chief for UNICEF Palestine.

;

;While UNICEF is bringing in medical supplies, he said, "distribution is becoming more and more difficult".

;

;Aid flows to Gaza have fallen sharply since Israel started shelling the Palestinian enclave in response to an attack by the Hamas militant group on Oct. 7 that killed 1,400 people.

;

;The death toll from the bombardment has caused international ;uproar;. Medical authorities in Hamas-run Gaza said on Tuesday that 8,525 people including 3,542 minors had been killed.

;

;Distribution is particularly hard in northern Gaza, the main focus of Israel's military operation, aid officials say, and some have halted all deliveries.

;

;World Health Organization (WHO) spokesperson Christian Lindmeier said on Tuesday it had sent no further aid to northern Gaza hospitals since Oct. 24, citing a lack of security guarantees.

;

;A public health catastrophe is ;imminent;, he said, amid the mass displacement and damage to water and sanitation infrastructure.

;

;He said there had been 82 attacks on healthcare facilities in Gaza since the conflict began on Oct. 7, with 491 people killed in the attacks, including 16 on duty health workers, and 28 ambulances damaged or destroyed.

;

;Rick Brennan, the WHO regional emergencies director, told Reuters that with 1.4 million people displaced in such a densely populated territory, conditions were dire.

;

;"The sanitation is atrocious, I mean I was just talking to an UNRWA colleague, she said the living conditions are sub-human. Where do people go to the bathroom? How do you remove all waste?"

;

;He said such a condition was ripe for the outbreak of diseases such as diarrhoea and respiratory and skin infections such as scabies.

;

;In Cairo, US Special Envoy David Satterfield, who has been negotiating with Israel and Egypt over aid deliveries, said providing humanitarian aid was critically important for Gaza, whose inhabitants say food and water have almost run out.

;

;"This is a society on edge and desperate… and the UN implementers must be able to demonstrate that aid is not episodic," he said in a briefing for reporters.

;

;Aid flows from Egypt have been slowed by an inspection system agreed with Israel in which trucks drive from Egypt's Rafah crossing along the Egypt-Israel border before returning towards Gaza. UNRWA's Touma called the system "way too cumbersome".
